2024-06-02 22:40:22: task=Extract the coursework information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, The first line contains the section name "Relevant Courses". The next lines contain the courses with the course name and 
  if provided, the programming languages used in the course in parentheses separated by a pipeline '|'. The courses should be separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX.
The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Similar to this: \section{Relevant Courses} 
  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
  Distributed Computing (Python | JavaScript) \\
  Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
  Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\
\sectionsep

Example: \section{Relevant Courses}

2024-06-02 22:53:39: task=Extract the coursework information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, The first line contains the section name "Relevant Courses". The next lines contain the courses with the course name and 
  if provided, the programming languages used in the course in parentheses separated by a pipeline '|'. The courses should be separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX.
The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example: \section{Relevant Courses} 
  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
  Distributed Computing (Python | JavaScript) \\
  Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
  Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\

  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

2024-06-02 23:13:50: task=Extract the education information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. If you don't find any information at all, the output should be completely empty.
In the output, The first line contains the section name "Education". The second line contains the university name. The third line contains the degree and major.  The fourth line contains the graduation date.  
Example:
\section{Education}
  \subsection{University of Manitoba}
  \summaryPoints{BSc Major in Computer Science}
  \subHeading{Graduated, October 2023}
\sectionsep

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-02 23:13:52: task=Extract the coursework information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, The first line contains the section name "Relevant Courses". The next lines contain the courses with the course name and 
  if provided, the programming languages used in the course in parentheses separated by a pipeline '|'. The courses should be separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX.
The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example: \section{Relevant Courses} 
  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
  Distributed Computing (Python | JavaScript) \\
  Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
  Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{Relevant Courses} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

2024-06-02 23:13:54: task=%\section{Relevant Courses}
%\sectionsep2024-06-02 23:13:54: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-02 23:13:54: task=Extract the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format.
In the output, The first line contains the section name "VOLUNTEER". The next lines contain the organization name, If the name is too long, do a split where seems appropriate the do a line break, then use \subHeading{} for the rest of the name. The next lines contain the organization name, role, and timeline, separated by pipeline '|'. The next lines contain the responsibilities, each starting with a dash '-' and separated by a newline command '\newline'. The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example 1: \section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \newline - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \sectionsep
Example 2 (If the organization name is too long): [suppose the organization name is "Student Union of the University of Manitoba"] \section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{Student Union} \subHeading{University of Manitoba} \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \newline - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \sectionsep
  
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{VOLUNTEER} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

\sectionsep2024-06-02 23:25:46: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-02 23:25:46: task=Extract the coursework information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, The first line contains the section name "Relevant Courses". The next lines contain the courses with the course name and 
  if provided, the programming languages used in the course in parentheses separated by a pipeline '|'. The courses should be separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX.
The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example: \section{Relevant Courses} 
  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
  Distributed Computing (Python | JavaScript) \\
  Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
  Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{Relevant Courses} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

%\sectionsep2024-06-02 23:25:47: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-02 23:25:47: task=Extract the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format.
In the output, The first line contains the section name "VOLUNTEER". The next lines contain the organization name, If the name is too long, do a split where seems appropriate the do a line break, then use \subHeading{} for the rest of the name. The next lines contain the organization name, role, and timeline, separated by pipeline '|'. The next lines contain the responsibilities, each starting with a dash '-' and separated by a newline command '\newline'. The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example 1: \section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \newline - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \sectionsep
use \skillsVSpace to start next \section{} if available.
Example 2 (If the organization name length is more than 20 chracters, use \subHeading{} instead of \subsection{}): \section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % If the name is too long, split it and use \subHeading{} \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \newline - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \sectionsep
  
Conditions: - If the organization name more than 22 chracters, use \subHeading{name} instead of \subsection{name} - Only generate the \section{VOLUNTEER} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

\sectionsep2024-06-02 23:33:39: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-02 23:33:39: task=Extract the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format.
In the output, The first line contains the section name "VOLUNTEER". The next lines contain the organization name, If the name is too long, do a split where seems appropriate the do a line break, then use \subHeading{} for the rest of the name. The next lines contain the organization name, role, and timeline, separated by pipeline '|'. The next lines contain the responsibilities, each starting with a dash '-' and separated by a newline command '\newline'. After all the responsibilities, use the command '\sectionsep'.
Example 1: \section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \newline - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \sectionsep
use \skillsVSpace to start next \section{} if available.
Example 2 (If the organization name length is more than 20 chracters, use \subHeading{} instead of \subsection{}): \section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % If the name is too long, use \subHeading{} \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \newline - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \sectionsep
  
Conditions: - If the organization name more than 22 chracters, use \subHeading{name} instead of \subsection{name} - Only generate the \section{VOLUNTEER} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

In the output, The first line contains the section name "Relevant Courses". The next lines contain the courses with the course name and 
  if provided, the programming languages used in the course in parentheses separated by a pipeline '|'. The courses should be separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX.
The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example: \section{Relevant Courses} 
  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
  Distributed Computing (Python | JavaScript) \\
  Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
  Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-02 23:42:05: task=Extract the coursework information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, The first line contains the section name "Relevant Courses". The next lines contain the courses with the course name and 
  if provided, the programming languages used in the course in parentheses separated by a pipeline '|'. The courses should be separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX.
The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example: \section{Relevant Courses} 
  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
  Distributed Computing (Python | JavaScript) \\
  Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
  Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{Relevant Courses} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-02 23:42:06: task=%\section{Relevant Courses}
%\sectionsep2024-06-02 23:42:06: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-02 23:42:06: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization names up to 22 characters.
   - For names longer than 22 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to ensure the name fits without breaking LaTeX formatting.
   - If the organization name is too long for one line, split the name at an appropriate point and continue on the next line with `\subHeading{}`.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) and separate them with `\newline` to clearly delineate individual tasks or contributions.

5. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

6. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \newline - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \newline - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \sectionsep
**Spacing Between Sections**: - Use `\skillsVSpace` to add vertical spacing before starting a new `\section{}` if another section follows the volunteer section.
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, leave the output blank without placeholder LaTeX comments.


{
  "Volunteer Work": [
    {
      "Organization Name": "Safe Bangladesh & Ar. Fawaz Rob",
      "Role": "Designer and builder",
      "Responsibilities": "Designed and had hands-on experience in building a small toilet from scratch using sustainable local materials.",
      "Timeline": "January 2019"
    },
    {
      "Organization Name": "Department of Architecture, North South University",
      "Role": "Volunteer",
      "Responsibilities": "Volunteered as an organizer and distributed invitations to other schools.",
      "Timeline": "March 2019"
    },
    {
      "Organization Name": "Department of Architecture, North South University",
      "Role": "Volunteer",
      "Responsibilities": "Volunteered as an organizer.",
      "Timeline": "June 2015"
    }
  ]
}2024-06-02 23:42:06: status=started
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-02 23:42:10: task=\section{VOLUNTEER}

\subHeading{Safe Bangladesh \& Ar. Fawaz Rob}

\subHeading{Designer and builder | January 2019}

- Designed and had hands-on experience in building a small toilet from scratch using sustainable local materials.

\newline

\subHeading{Department of Architecture, North South University}

\subHeading{Volunteer | March 2019}

- Volunteered as an organizer and distributed invitations to other schools.

\newline

\subHeading{Department of Architecture, North South University}

\subHeading{Volunteer | June 2015}

- Volunteered as an organizer.

 % \sectionsep2024-06-02 23:45:23: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-02 23:45:23: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization names up to 22 characters.
   - For names longer than 22 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to ensure the name fits without breaking LaTeX formatting.
   - If the organization name is too long for one line, split the name at an appropriate point and continue on the next line with `\subHeading{}`.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) and separate them with `\newline` to clearly delineate individual tasks or contributions.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\sectionsep` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   

5. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

6. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \newline - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \newline - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \sectionsep
**Spacing Between Sections**: - Use `\skillsVSpace` to add vertical spacing before starting a new `\section{}` if another section follows the volunteer section.
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, leave the output blank without placeholder LaTeX comments.

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-02 23:47:29: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization names up to 22 characters.
   - For names longer than 22 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to ensure the name fits without breaking LaTeX formatting.
   - If the organization name is too long for one line, split the name at an appropriate point and continue on the next line with `\subHeading{}`.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) and separate them with `\newline` to clearly delineate individual tasks or contributions.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\sectionsep` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:

**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \newline - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \sectionsep
**Spacing Between Sections**: - Use `\skillsVSpace` to add vertical spacing before starting a new `\section{}` if another section follows the volunteer section.
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, leave the output blank without placeholder LaTeX comments.

  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{Relevant Courses} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

    "Relevant Coursework (to the Job Description)": []

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-02 23:51:01: task=%\section{Relevant Courses}
%\sectionsep2024-06-02 23:51:01: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-02 23:51:01: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization names up to 20 characters.
   - For organization names longer than 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to ensure the name fits without breaking LaTeX formatting.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) and separate them with `\newline` to clearly delineate individual tasks or contributions.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\sectionsep` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \newline - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \newline - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, leave the output blank without placeholder LaTeX comments.

      "Organization Name": "Department of Architecture, North South University",
      "Role": "Volunteer",

      "Timeline": "June 2015"
    }
  ]

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-02 23:53:03: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization names up to 20 characters.
   - For organization names longer than 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` instead of '\subsection{}'. This is to maintain consistent formatting and avoid layout issues.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) and separate them with `\newline` to clearly delineate individual tasks or contributions.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\sectionsep` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \newline - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \newline - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \sectionsep

2024-06-03 11:43:20: task=Extract the coursework information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, The first line contains the section name "Relevant Courses". The next lines contain the courses with the course name and 
  if provided, the programming languages used in the course in parentheses separated by a pipeline '|'. The courses should be separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX.
The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example: \section{Relevant Courses} 
  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
  Distributed Computing (Python | JavaScript) \\
  Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
  Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 11:43:22: task=%\section{}
%\sectionsep2024-06-03 11:43:22: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 11:43:22: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization names less than 20 characters. Otherwise, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain consistent formatting and avoid layout issues.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\skillsVSpace \skillsVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \\ \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \\ \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, leave the output blank without placeholder LaTeX comments.

**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization names less than 20 characters. Otherwise, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain consistent formatting and avoid layout issues.

   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\skillsVSpace \skillsVSpace` (2 times) to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.

   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

  \summaryPoints{Bachelor of Architecture (B.Arch)}
\subHeading{Graduated, Jan 2021}
\sectionsep2024-06-03 11:47:36: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 11:47:36: task=Extract the coursework information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, The first line contains the section name "Relevant Courses". The next lines contain the courses with the course name and 
  if provided, the programming languages used in the course in parentheses separated by a pipeline '|'. The courses should be separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX.
The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example: \section{Relevant Courses} 
  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
  Distributed Computing (Python | JavaScript) \\
  Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
  Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{Relevant Courses} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.


{
    "Relevant Coursework (to the Job Description)": []
  }2024-06-03 11:47:36: status=started
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 11:47:38: task=%\section{Relevant Courses}
%\sectionsep2024-06-03 11:47:38: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 11:47:38: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. Otherwise, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain consistent formatting and avoid layout issues.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} % not using \subHeading{} due to the name less than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \\ \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, leave the output blank without placeholder LaTeX comments.


{
  "Volunteer Work": [
    {
      "Organization Name": "Safe Bangladesh & Ar. Fawaz Rob",

      "Organization Name": "Department of Architecture, North South University",
      "Role": "Volunteer",
      "Responsibilities": "Volunteered as an organizer.",
      "Timeline": "June 2015"
    }
  ]

**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`

     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:

**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \\ \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, leave the output blank without placeholder LaTeX comments.

2024-06-03 11:52:32: task=Extract the coursework information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, The first line contains the section name "Relevant Courses". The next lines contain the courses with the course name and 
  if provided, the programming languages used in the course in parentheses separated by a pipeline '|'. The courses should be separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX.
The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example: \section{Relevant Courses} 
  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
  Distributed Computing (Python | JavaScript) \\
  Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
  Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\

  %\section{}

  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

2024-06-03 11:52:34: task=%\section{Relevant Courses}
  %\sectionsep2024-06-03 11:52:34: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 11:52:34: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. Otherwise, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain consistent formatting and avoid layout issues.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \\ \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. \\ \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, leave the output blank without placeholder LaTeX comments.

In the output, The first line contains the section name "Education". The second line contains the university name. The third line contains the degree and major.  The fourth line contains the graduation date.  
Example:
\section{Education}
  \subsection{University of Manitoba}
  \summaryPoints{BSc Major in Computer Science}
  \subHeading{Graduated, October 2023}
\sectionsep

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 19:12:15: task=Extract the coursework information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, The first line contains the section name "Relevant Courses". The next lines contain the courses with the course name and 
  if provided, the programming languages used in the course in parentheses separated by a pipeline '|'. The courses should be separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX.
The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example: \section{Relevant Courses} 
  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
  Distributed Computing (Python | JavaScript) \\
  Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
  Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{Relevant Courses} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 19:12:16: task=%\section{Relevant Courses}
%\sectionsep2024-06-03 19:12:16: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 19:12:16: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. Otherwise, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain consistent formatting and avoid layout issues.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, leave the output blank without placeholder LaTeX comments.


{
  "Volunteer Work": [
    {
      "Organization Name": "Safe Bangladesh & Ar. Fawaz Rob",
      "Name length in characters": 31,
      "Role": "Designer and builder",
      "Responsibilities": "Designed and had hands-on experience in building a small toilet from scratch using sustainable local materials.",
      "Timeline": "January 2019"
    },
    {
      "Organization Name": "Department of Architecture, North South University",
      "Name length in characters": 50,
      "Role": "Volunteer",
      "Responsibilities": "Volunteered as an organizer and distributed invitations to other schools.",
      "Timeline": "March 2019"
    },
    {
      "Organization Name": "Department of Architecture, North South University",
      "Name length in characters": 50,
      "Role": "Volunteer",
      "Responsibilities": "Volunteered as an organizer.",
      "Timeline": "June 2015"
    }
  ]
}2024-06-03 19:12:16: status=started

 \entryVSpace

 \entryVSpace

**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. Otherwise, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain consistent formatting and avoid layout issues.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, leave the output blank without placeholder LaTeX comments.

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 19:21:53: task=Extract the references information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the section name "References". - The next line contain the references with the name, - The next line contains the position, company. - The next line contains the contact information, email, phone number, location. Each of these should be started with a '-' and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the relationship. - The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections, or if there are multiple references, use '\entryVSpace' to separate each reference.
Example: \section{References} 
  \subsection{Dr. John Doe}
  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}
  - Email: drjohndoe@example.com \\
  - Phone: 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Academic Advisor \\
  
  \entryVSpace

\subsection{Jane Smith}
  \subHeading{Manager | ABC Company}
  - Email: example@example.com
  - Phone: 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Former Supervisor \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{References} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 19:42:12: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, leave the output blank without placeholder LaTeX comments.

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 19:43:47: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, leave the output blank without placeholder LaTeX comments.

2024-06-03 19:43:51: task=Extract the references information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the section name "References". - The next line contain the references with the name, - The next line contains the position, company. - The next line contains the contact information, email, phone number, location. Each of these should be started with a '-' and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the relationship. - The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections, or if there are multiple references, use '\entryVSpace' to separate each reference.
Example: \section{References} 
  \subsection{Dr. John Doe}
  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}
  - drjohndoe@example.com \\
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Academic Advisor \\
  
  \entryVSpace

\subsection{Jane Smith}
  \subHeading{Manager | ABC Company}
  - example@example.com
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Former Supervisor \\
\sectionsep

  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

2024-06-03 19:43:57: task=Extract the experience information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the command \betweenProjectsVSpace. - The next line contains the section name "Experience" or "Project Experience" or "Academic Projecr" based on the context provided. - The next line contains the experience title. - The next line contains the summary points. Each point should be Separated by a pipeline '|', and the last point should not have a pipeline at the end. - The next line contains the subheading with the role and timeline. - The next line contains the description of the experience.  - The next line contains the command \vspace{15pt} for the first experience and \vspace{10pt} for the rest of the experiences. - The next line contains the command \begin{tightemize} to start the list of responsibilities. - The next lines contain the responsibilities starting with a '\item' command. Each responsibility should be started with a '\item' command and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the command \end{tightemize} to end the list of responsibilities. - The next line contains the command \sectionsep to separate the sections.
Example: \betweenProjectsVSpace \experienceTitle{ATS Pass AI} \summaryPoints{Python | Multiagent | AI | RAG Search} \subHeading{Resume Automation Tool - January 2024 - Present} \betweensummaryPointsionVSpace Led the development of a multi-agent system with CrewAI, LangChain, Gemini, and RAG Search to create tailored resumes to enhance job search efficiency. \vspace{15pt} \begin{tightemize} \item Utilized advanced AI models and \textbf{multi-agent} technologies to dynamically personalize resumes, demonstrating cutting-edge technical and analytical capabilities. \item Engineered a system that extracts user data and analyzes job summary points with advanced AI tools like Gemini Pro and RAG Search, to craft a resume and \textbf{achieve over 85\% keyword alignment} and optimize resumes for ATS. \item Developed \textbf{scalable architecture} to anticipate future needs and adaptations, showcasing foresight and a commitment to innovation. \item Project repository available on \href{https://github.com/vmsaif/ats-pass-ai}{\underline{GitHub}}. \end{tightemize} \sectionsep

  if provided, the programming languages used in the course in parentheses separated by a pipeline '|'. The courses should be separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX.
The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example: \section{Relevant Courses} 
  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
  Distributed Computing (Python | JavaScript) \\
  Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
  Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{Relevant Courses} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

%\sectionsep2024-06-03 19:47:04: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 19:47:04: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, leave the output blank without placeholder LaTeX comments.

2024-06-03 19:47:08: task=Extract the references information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the section name "References". - The next line contain the references with the name, - The next line contains the position, company. - The next line contains the contact information, email, phone number, location. Each of these should be started with a '-' and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the relationship. - The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections, or if there are multiple references, use '\entryVSpace' to separate each reference.
Example: \section{References} 
  \subsection{Dr. John Doe}
  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}
  - drjohndoe@example.com \\
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Academic Advisor \\
  
  \entryVSpace

\subsection{Jane Smith}
  \subHeading{Manager | ABC Company}
  - example@example.com
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Former Supervisor \\
\sectionsep

  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

Each point should be Separated by a pipeline '|', and the last point should not have a pipeline at the end. - The next line contains the subheading with the role and timeline. - The next line contains the description of the experience.  - The next line contains the command \vspace{15pt} for the first experience and \vspace{10pt} for the rest of the experiences. - The next line contains the command \begin{tightemize} to start the list of responsibilities. - The next lines contain the responsibilities starting with a '\item' command. %\sectionsep2024-06-03 19:52:00: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 19:52:00: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, leave the output blank without placeholder LaTeX comments.


{
  "Volunteer Work": [
    {
      "Organization Name": "Safe Bangladesh & Ar. Fawaz Rob",
      "Name length in characters": 31,
      "Role": "Designer and builder",
      "Responsibilities": "Designed and had hands-on experience in building a small toilet from scratch using sustainable local materials.",
      "Timeline": "January 2019"
    },
    {
      "Organization Name": "Department of Architecture, North South University",
      "Name length in characters": 50,
      "Role": "Volunteer",
      "Responsibilities": "Volunteered as an organizer and distributed invitations to other schools.",
      "Timeline": "March 2019"
    },

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 19:52:04: task=Extract the references information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the section name "References". - The next line contain the references with the name, - The next line contains the position, company. - The next line contains the contact information, email, phone number, location. Each of these should be started with a '-' and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the relationship. - The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections, or if there are multiple references, use '\entryVSpace' to separate each reference.
Example: \section{References} 
  \subsection{Dr. John Doe}
  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}
  - drjohndoe@example.com \\
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Academic Advisor \\
  
  \entryVSpace

\subsection{Jane Smith}
  \subHeading{Manager | ABC Company}
  - example@example.com
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Former Supervisor \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{References} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

2024-06-03 19:52:12: task=Extract the experience information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the command \betweenProjectsVSpace. - The next line contains the section name "Experience" or "Project Experience" or "Academic Projecr" based on the context provided, \section{Experience} or \section{Project Experience} or \section{Academic Project}. - The next line contains the experience title. \experienceTitle{Experience Title} or \experienceTitle{Project Title} or \experienceTitle{Academic Project Title}. - The next line contains the summary points. Each point should be Separated by a pipeline '|', and the last point should not have a pipeline at the end. (Maximum 4 points) - The next line contains the subheading with the role and timeline. - The next line contains the description of the experience.  - The next line contains the command \vspace{15pt} for the first experience and \vspace{10pt} for the rest of the experiences. - The next line contains the command \begin{tightemize} to start the list of responsibilities. - The next lines contain the responsibilities starting with a '\item' command. Each responsibility should be started with a '\item' command and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the command \end{tightemize} to end the list of responsibilities. - The next line contains the command \sectionsep to separate the sections.
Example: \betweenProjectsVSpace \experienceTitle{ATS Pass AI} \summaryPoints{Python | Multiagent | AI | RAG Search} \subHeading{Resume Automation Tool - January 2024 - Present} \betweensummaryPointsionVSpace Led the development of a multi-agent system with CrewAI, LangChain, Gemini, and RAG Search to create tailored resumes to enhance job search efficiency. \vspace{15pt} \begin{tightemize} \item Utilized advanced AI models and \textbf{multi-agent} technologies to dynamically personalize resumes, demonstrating cutting-edge technical and analytical capabilities. \item Engineered a system that extracts user data and analyzes job summary points with advanced AI tools like Gemini Pro and RAG Search, to craft a resume and \textbf{achieve over 85\% keyword alignment} and optimize resumes for ATS. \item Developed \textbf{scalable architecture} to anticipate future needs and adaptations, showcasing foresight and a commitment to innovation. \item Project repository available on \href{https://github.com/vmsaif/ats-pass-ai}{\underline{GitHub}}. \end{tightemize} \sectionsep

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 19:55:56: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, leave the output blank without placeholder LaTeX comments.

Each point should be Separated by a pipeline '|', and the last point should not have a pipeline at the end. (Maximum 4 points) - The next line contains the subheading with the role and timeline. - The next line contains the description of the experience.  - The next line contains the command \vspace{15pt} for the first experience and \vspace{10pt} for the rest of the experiences. - The next line contains the command \begin{tightemize} to start the list of responsibilities. - The next lines contain the responsibilities starting with a '\item' command. Each responsibility should be started with a '\item' command. - The next line contains the command \end{tightemize} to end the list of responsibilities. - The next line contains the command \sectionsep to separate the sections.
Example: \betweenProjectsVSpace \experienceTitle{ATS Pass AI} \summaryPoints{Python | Multiagent | AI | RAG Search} \subHeading{Resume Automation Tool - January 2024 - Present} \betweensummaryPointsionVSpace Led the development of a multi-agent system with CrewAI, LangChain, Gemini, and RAG Search to create tailored resumes to enhance job search efficiency. \vspace{15pt} \begin{tightemize} \item Utilized advanced AI models and \textbf{multi-agent} technologies to dynamically personalize resumes, demonstrating cutting-edge technical and analytical capabilities. \item Engineered a system that extracts user data and analyzes job summary points with advanced AI tools like Gemini Pro and RAG Search, to craft a resume and \textbf{achieve over 85\% keyword alignment} and optimize resumes for ATS. \item Developed \textbf{scalable architecture} to anticipate future needs and adaptations, showcasing foresight and a commitment to innovation. \item Project repository available on \href{https://github.com/vmsaif/ats-pass-ai}{\underline{GitHub}}. \end{tightemize}

Example: \section{Relevant Courses} 
  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\

%\sectionsep2024-06-03 19:57:07: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 19:57:07: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, leave the output blank without placeholder LaTeX comments.

2024-06-03 19:57:11: task=Extract the references information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the section name "References". - The next line contain the references with the name, - The next line contains the position, company. - The next line contains the contact information, email, phone number, location. Each of these should be started with a '-' and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the relationship. - The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections, or if there are multiple references, use '\entryVSpace' to separate each reference.
Example: \section{References} 
  \subsection{Dr. John Doe}
  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}
  - drjohndoe@example.com \\
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Academic Advisor \\
  
  \entryVSpace

\subsection{Jane Smith}
  \subHeading{Manager | ABC Company}
  - example@example.com
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Former Supervisor \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{References} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

Each point should be Separated by a pipeline '|', and the last point should not have a pipeline at the end. (Maximum 4 points) - The next line contains the subheading with the role and timeline. - The next line contains the description of the experience.  - The next line contains the command \vspace{15pt} for the first experience and \vspace{10pt} for the rest of the experiences. - The next line contains the command \begin{tightemize} to start the list of responsibilities. - The next lines contain the responsibilities starting with a '\item' command. The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.

  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
  Distributed Computing (Python | JavaScript) \\
  Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
  Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\

  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 19:59:51: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, leave the output blank without placeholder LaTeX comments.
