In the output, - The first line contains the section name "References". - The next line contain the references with the name, - The next line contains the position, company. - The next line contains the contact information, email, phone number, location. Each of these should be started with a '-' and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the relationship. - The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections, or if there are multiple references, use '\entryVSpace' to separate each reference.
Example: \section{References} 
  \subsection{Dr. John Doe}
  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}
  - drjohndoe@example.com \\
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Academic Advisor \\
  
  \entryVSpace

\subsection{Jane Smith}
  \subHeading{Manager | ABC Company}
  - example@example.com
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Former Supervisor \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{References} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

In the output, The first line contains the section name "Relevant Courses". The next lines contain the courses with the course name and 
  if provided, the programming languages used in the course in parentheses separated by a pipeline '|'. The courses should be separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX.
The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example: \section{Relevant Courses} 
  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
  Distributed Computing (Python | JavaScript) \\
  Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
  Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\

  %\sectionsep.

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 20:06:00: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.

2024-06-03 20:06:05: task=Extract the references information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the section name "References". - The next line contain the references with the name, - The next line contains the position, company. - The next line contains the contact information, email, phone number, location. Each of these should be started with a '-' and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the relationship. - The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections, or if there are multiple references, use '\entryVSpace' to separate each reference.
Example: \section{References} 
  \subsection{Dr. John Doe}
  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}
  - drjohndoe@example.com \\
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Academic Advisor \\
  
  \entryVSpace

\subsection{Jane Smith}
  \subHeading{Manager | ABC Company}
  - example@example.com
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Former Supervisor \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{References} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

2024-06-03 20:06:11: task=Extract the experience information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the command \betweenProjectsVSpace. **This is important** - The next line contains the section name "Experience" or "Project Experience" or "Academic Projecr" based on the context provided, \section{Experience} or \section{Project Experience} or \section{Academic Project}. - The next line contains the experience title. \experienceTitle{Experience Title} or \experienceTitle{Project Title} or \experienceTitle{Academic Project Title}. - The next line contains the summary points upto 3 points. Each point should be Separated by a pipeline '|', and the last point should not have a pipeline at the end. **(Maximum 3 points)** - The next line contains the subheading with the role and timeline. - The next line contains the description of the experience.  - The next line contains the command \vspace{15pt} for the first experience and \vspace{10pt} for the rest of the experiences. - The next line contains the command \begin{tightemize} to start the list of responsibilities. - The next lines contain the responsibilities starting with a '\item' command. Each responsibility should be started with a '\item' command. - The next line contains the command \end{tightemize} to end the list of responsibilities. - The next line contains the command \sectionsep to separate the sections. - Each command is important.
Example: \betweenProjectsVSpace \experienceTitle{ATS Pass AI} \summaryPoints{Python | Multiagent | AI} % Maximum 3 points \subHeading{Resume Automation Tool - January 2024 - Present} \betweensummaryPointsionVSpace Led the development of a multi-agent system with CrewAI, LangChain, Gemini, and RAG Search to create tailored resumes to enhance job search efficiency. \vspace{15pt} \begin{tightemize} \item Utilized advanced AI models ... \item Engineered a system ... \item Developed \textbf{scalable architecture} to .. \item Project repository available on \href{https://github.com/vmsaif/ats-pass-ai}{\underline{GitHub}}. \end{tightemize}

2024-06-03 20:07:54: task=Extract the coursework information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, The first line contains the section name "Relevant Courses". The next lines contain the courses with the course name and 
  if provided, the programming languages used in the course in parentheses separated by a pipeline '|'. The courses should be separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX.
The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example: \section{Relevant Courses} 
  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
  Distributed Computing (Python | JavaScript) \\
  Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
  Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{Relevant Courses} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 20:07:55: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.


{
  "Volunteer Work": [
    {
      "Organization Name": "Safe Bangladesh & Ar. Fawaz Rob",

    },

2024-06-03 20:07:59: task=Extract the references information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the section name "References". - The next line contain the references with the name, - The next line contains the position, company. - The next line contains the contact information, email, phone number, location. Each of these should be started with a '-' and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the relationship. - The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections, or if there are multiple references, use '\entryVSpace' to separate each reference.
Example: \section{References} 
  \subsection{Dr. John Doe}
  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}
  - drjohndoe@example.com \\
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Academic Advisor \\
  
  \entryVSpace

\subsection{Jane Smith}
  \subHeading{Manager | ABC Company}
  - example@example.com
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Former Supervisor \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{References} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

2024-06-03 20:08:07: task=Extract the experience information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the command \betweenProjectsVSpace. **This is important** - The next line contains the section name "Experience" or "Project Experience" or "Academic Projecr" based on the context provided, \section{Experience} or \section{Project Experience} or \section{Academic Project}. - The next line contains the experience title. \experienceTitle{Experience Title} or \experienceTitle{Project Title} or \experienceTitle{Academic Project Title}. - The next line contains the summary points up to 3 points. Each point should be Separated by a pipeline '|', and the last point should not have a pipeline at the end. **(Maximum 3 points)** - The next line contains the subheading with the role and timeline. - The next line contains the description of the experience.  - The next line contains the command \vspace{15pt} for the first experience and \vspace{10pt} for the rest of the experiences. - The next line contains the command \begin{tightemize} to start the list of responsibilities. - The next lines contain the responsibilities starting with a '\item' command. Each responsibility should be started with a '\item' command. - The next line contains the command \end{tightemize} to end the list of responsibilities. - The next line contains the command \sectionsep to separate the sections. - Each command is important.
Example: \betweenProjectsVSpace \experienceTitle{ATS Pass AI} \summaryPoints{Python | Multiagent | AI} % Choose up to 3 points \subHeading{Resume Automation Tool - January 2024 - Present} \betweensummaryPointsVSpace Led the development of a multi-agent system with CrewAI, LangChain, Gemini, and RAG Search to create tailored resumes to enhance job search efficiency. \vspace{15pt} \begin{tightemize} \item Utilized advanced AI models ... \item Engineered a system ... \item Developed \textbf{scalable architecture} to .. \item Project repository available on \href{https://github.com/vmsaif/ats-pass-ai}{\underline{GitHub}}. \end{tightemize}

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-03 20:09:44: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.

2024-06-03 20:09:48: task=Extract the references information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the section name "References". - The next line contain the references with the name, - The next line contains the position, company. - The next line contains the contact information, email, phone number, location. Each of these should be started with a '-' and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the relationship. - The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections, or if there are multiple references, use '\entryVSpace' to separate each reference.
Example: \section{References} 
  \subsection{Dr. John Doe}
  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}
  - drjohndoe@example.com \\
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Academic Advisor \\
  
  \entryVSpace

\subsection{Jane Smith}
  \subHeading{Manager | ABC Company}
  - example@example.com
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Former Supervisor \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{References} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

%\sectionsep2024-06-04 09:04:58: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-04 09:04:58: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.


{
  "Volunteer Work": [
    {
      "Organization Name": "UniAssist Global Education",
      "Name length in characters": 26,
      "Role": "Graphic Designer",
      "Responsibilities": "- Designed and prepared banners, backdrops and brochures for Education Expo 2019.\n- Designed the official logo, social media posts, receipts and other official document formats.",
      "Timeline": "Sep 2019 - Dec 2019"
    },
    {
      "Organization Name": "Safe Bangladesh & Ar. Fawaz Rob",
      "Name length in characters": 31,
      "Role": "Designer and builder",
      "Responsibilities": "Designed and had a hand on experience on how to properly build a small toilet from scratch by using sustainable local materials.",
      "Timeline": "January 2019"
    }
  ]

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-04 09:05:02: task=Extract the references information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the section name "References". - The next line contain the references with the name, - The next line contains the position, company. - The next line contains the contact information, email, phone number, location. Each of these should be started with a '-' and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the relationship. - The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections, or if there are multiple references, use '\entryVSpace' to separate each reference.
Example: \section{References} 
  \subsection{Dr. John Doe}
  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}
  - drjohndoe@example.com \\
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Academic Advisor \\
  
  \entryVSpace

\subsection{Jane Smith}
  \subHeading{Manager | ABC Company}
  - example@example.com
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Former Supervisor \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{References} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

2024-06-04 09:05:06: task=Extract the experience information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the command \betweenProjectsVSpace. **This is important** - The next line contains the section name "Experience" or "Project Experience" or "Academic Projecr" based on the context provided, \section{Experience} or \section{Project Experience} or \section{Academic Project}. - The next line contains the experience title. \experienceTitle{Experience Title} or \experienceTitle{Project Title} or \experienceTitle{Academic Project Title}. - The next line contains the summary points up to 3 points. It will start with a space and a pipeline '|', each point should be Separated by a pipeline '|', and the last point should not have a pipeline at the end. **(Maximum 3 points)**, use the command \summaryPoints{ | Point 1 | Point 2 | Point 3} to start the summary points. - The next line contains the subheading with the role and timeline. - The next line contains the description of the experience.  - The next line contains the command \vspace{15pt} for the first experience and \vspace{10pt} for the rest of the experiences. - The next line contains the command \begin{tightemize} to start the list of responsibilities. - The next lines contain the responsibilities starting with a '\item' command. Each responsibility should be started with a '\item' command. - The next line contains the command \end{tightemize} to end the list of responsibilities. - The next line contains the command \sectionsep to separate the sections. - Each command is important.
Example: \betweenProjectsVSpace \experienceTitle{ATS Pass AI} \summaryPoints{ | Python | Multiagent | AI} % Choose up to 3 points \subHeading{Resume Automation Tool - January 2024 - Present} \betweensummaryPointsVSpace Led the development of a multi-agent system with CrewAI, LangChain, Gemini, and RAG Search to create tailored resumes to enhance job search efficiency. \vspace{15pt} \begin{tightemize} \item Utilized advanced AI models ... \item Engineered a system ... \item Developed \textbf{scalable architecture} to .. \item Project repository available on \href{https://github.com/vmsaif/ats-pass-ai}{\underline{GitHub}}. \end{tightemize}

2024-06-04 09:13:00: task=Extract the coursework information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, The first line contains the section name "Relevant Courses". The next lines contain the courses with the course name and 
  if provided, the programming languages used in the course in parentheses separated by a pipeline '|'. The courses should be separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX.
The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example: \section{Relevant Courses} 
  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
  Distributed Computing (Python | JavaScript) \\
  Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
  Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\
\sectionsep

  %\sectionsep.

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-04 09:13:02: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.

Example: \section{References}

  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}

% \sectionsep2024-06-04 09:20:51: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-04 09:20:51: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.

2024-06-04 09:20:55: task=Extract the references information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the section name "References". - The next line contain the references with the name, - The next line contains the position, company. - The next line contains the contact information, email, phone number, location. Each of these should be started with a '-' and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the relationship. - The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections, or if there are multiple references, use '\entryVSpace' to separate each reference.
Example: \section{References} 
  \subsection{Dr. John Doe}
  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}
  - drjohndoe@example.com \\
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Academic Advisor \\
  
  \entryVSpace

\subsection{Jane Smith}
  \subHeading{Manager | ABC Company}
  - example@example.com
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Former Supervisor \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{References} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.

In the output, The first line contains the section name "Relevant Courses". The next lines contain the courses with the course name and 
  if provided, the programming languages used in the course in parentheses separated by a pipeline '|'. The courses should be separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX.
The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example: \section{Relevant Courses} 
  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
  Distributed Computing (Python | JavaScript) \\
  Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
  Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-04 09:33:40: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
- I will save your output durectly into a a LaTeX file (.tex), so make sure to use % for any comments.

2024-06-04 09:33:44: task=Extract the references information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the section name "References". - The next line contain the references with the name, - The next line contains the position, company. - The next line contains the contact information, email, phone number, location. Each of these should be started with a '-' and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the relationship. - The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections, or if there are multiple references, use '\entryVSpace' to separate each reference.
Example: \section{References} 
  \subsection{Dr. John Doe}
  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}
  - drjohndoe@example.com \\
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Academic Advisor \\
  
  \entryVSpace

\subsection{Jane Smith}
  \subHeading{Manager | ABC Company}
  - example@example.com
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Former Supervisor \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{References} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.
- I will save your output durectly into a a LaTeX file (.tex), so make sure to use % for any comments.

2024-06-04 09:36:15: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep

2024-06-04 09:36:20: task=Extract the references information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the section name "References". - The next line contain the references with the name, - The next line contains the position, company. - The next line contains the contact information, email, phone number, location. Each of these should be started with a '-' and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the relationship. - The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections, or if there are multiple references, use '\entryVSpace' to separate each reference.
Example: \section{References} 
  \subsection{Dr. John Doe}
  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}
  - drjohndoe@example.com \\
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Academic Advisor \\
  
  \entryVSpace

\subsection{Jane Smith}
  \subHeading{Manager | ABC Company}
  - example@example.com
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Former Supervisor \\
\sectionsep

2024-06-04 09:41:00: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-04 09:47:16: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
- Your output should only follow latex syntax.

2024-06-04 09:47:20: task=Extract the references information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the section name "References". - The next line contain the references with the name, - The next line contains the position, company. - The next line contains the contact information, email, phone number, location. Each of these should be started with a '-' and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the relationship. - The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections, or if there are multiple references, use '\entryVSpace' to separate each reference.
Example: \section{References} 
  \subsection{Dr. John Doe}
  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}
  - drjohndoe@example.com \\
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Academic Advisor \\
  
  \entryVSpace

  \subHeading{Manager | ABC Company}
  - example@example.com
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Former Supervisor \\
\sectionsep

  %\sectionsep.

In the output, The first line contains the section name "Relevant Courses". The next lines contain the courses with the course name and 
  if provided, the programming languages used in the course in parentheses separated by a pipeline '|'. The courses should be separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX.
The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example: \section{Relevant Courses} 
  Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
  Distributed Computing (Python | JavaScript) \\
  Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
  Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
  Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-04 09:51:30: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
- - Your output should follow latex syntax, no need for any code block quotes.

2024-06-04 09:51:35: task=Extract the references information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the section name "References". - The next line contain the references with the name, - The next line contains the position, company. - The next line contains the contact information, email, phone number, location. Each of these should be started with a '-' and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the relationship. - The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections, or if there are multiple references, use '\entryVSpace' to separate each reference.
Example: \section{References} 
  \subsection{Dr. John Doe}
  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}
  - drjohndoe@example.com \\
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Academic Advisor \\
  
  \entryVSpace

\subsection{Jane Smith}
  \subHeading{Manager | ABC Company}
  - example@example.com
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Former Supervisor \\
\sectionsep
Conditions: - Only generate the \section{References} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, the output should be blank as 
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.
- - Your output should follow latex syntax, no need for any code block quotes.

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-04 10:14:46: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
- - Your output should follow latex syntax, no need for any code block quotes.

The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections.
Example: \section{Relevant Courses}

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-04 10:17:28: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
- - Your output should follow latex syntax, no need for any code block quotes.

2024-06-04 10:17:32: task=Extract the references information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. 
In the output, - The first line contains the section name "References". - The next line contain the references with the name, - The next line contains the position, company. - The next line contains the contact information, email, phone number, location. Each of these should be started with a '-' and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the relationship. - The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections, or if there are multiple references, use '\entryVSpace' to separate each reference.
Example: \section{References} 
  \subsection{Dr. John Doe}
  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}
  - drjohndoe@example.com \\
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Academic Advisor \\
  
  \entryVSpace

  \subHeading{Manager | ABC Company}
  - example@example.com
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Former Supervisor \\
\sectionsep

  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
  Do Nothing else. Keep the output empty.
- - Your output should follow latex syntax, no need for any code block quotes.

   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subHeading{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subHeading{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\entryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subHeading{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subHeading{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subHeading{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subHeading{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \entryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
- - Your output should follow latex syntax, no need for any code block quotes.

In the output, - The first line contains the section name "References". - The next line contain the references with the name, - The next line contains the position, company. - The next line contains the contact information, email, phone number, location. Each of these should be started with a '-' and separated by a double backslash '\\' which is the line break command in LaTeX. - The next line contains the relationship. - The last line contains the command '\sectionsep' to separate the sections, or if there are multiple references, use '\entryVSpace' to separate each reference.
Example: \section{References} 
  \subsection{Dr. John Doe}
  \subHeading{Professor | University of Manitoba}
  - drjohndoe@example.com \\
  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Academic Advisor \\

  - 123 456 7890 \\
  - Relationship: Former Supervisor \\

  \subsection{University of Manitoba} (Choose up to 2 educations)
  \summaryPoints{BSc Major in Computer Science}
  \subHeading{Graduated, October 2023}
\sectionsep
\newEntryVSpace % use it if there are multiple educations.

Conditions: - Only generate the \section{Education} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, each line the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep. 
- Your output should follow latex syntax, no need for any code block quotes.

In the output,  - The first line contains the name. Use the command \namesection{First Name}{Last Name}. - Then the next line will contain the urls. Use the command \urlstyle{same} to keep the urls in the same style as the text. The line will contain urls upto 2. then \\ to linebreak. Use \href for the urls. The argument of \href should be the url and the text should be the url without the protocol. - The thirdline will contain the email, phone number, and location. Use the command \href for the email. The argument of \href should be the email and the text should be the email. The phone number should be in the format of 204 955 5064. The location should be in the format of City, Province. - Pipeline '|' should be used to separate the data and must not be the last character of the output. - The output should raw latex code and should not be in a code block.

agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-06 21:54:35: task=Extract the education information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. If you don't find any information at all, the output should be completely empty.
In the output, The first line contains the section name "Education" with the command \section{Education}. The second line contains the university name with the command \customTitle{}. The third line contains the degree and major with the command \semiTitle{}. The fourth line contains the graduation date with the command \subHeading{}.
Example:
\section{Education}
  \subsection{University of Manitoba} (Choose up to 2 educations)
  \summaryPoints{BSc Major in Computer Science}
  \subHeading{Graduated, October 2023}
\sectionsep
\newEntryVSpace % use it if there are multiple educations.

Conditions: - Only generate the \section{Education} if there is at least one element provided. Otherwise, each line the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep. 
- Your output should follow latex syntax, no need for any code block quotes.

  - use the command \body{} to list the courses. Each course should be on a new line with a double backslash '\\' at the end of each line.
  - Each course should be in the format "Course Name (Language | Framework)". Use the pipe '|' to separate the language and framework. If there is no language or framework, leave it blank.
  - Use the command \sectionsep at the end to separate the coursework from other sections.
Example: \section{Relevant Courses} \body{
    Operating Systems (Linux | C) \\
    Distributed Computing (Python) \\
    Database Implementation (Python | SQL) \\
    Data Structures and Algorithms (Java) \\
    Object Orientation (Java | C++) \\
    Software Engineering (Java | Unit Testing)
} \sectionsep

% \sectionsep2024-06-06 22:18:29: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-06 22:19:07: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subTitle{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subTitle{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\newEntryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} \subTitle{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} \body{
  - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. 
  - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. 
} \newEntryVSpace \sectionsep
**Example 2 - Long Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{Student Union of University of Manitoba} % Using \subTitle{} due to length is greater than 20 characters \subTitle{Active Member | 2019-2023} - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies.  \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
- Your output should be raw LaTeX code and should not be in a code block.


{
  "Volunteer Work": [
    {
      "Organization Name": "UniAssist Global Education",
      "Name length in characters": 26,
      "Role": "Graphic Designer",

\sectionsep2024-06-06 22:19:12: status=completed
agent=LaTeX Code Generator
2024-06-06 22:30:14: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\subTitle{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subTitle{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) always use `\\` for line breaks.

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\newEntryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1 - Short Organization Name**:
\section{VOLUNTEER} \subsection{.dev Programming Club} or \subTitle{.dev Programming Club} (if the name exceeds 20 characters) \subTitle{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023} \body{
  - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. 
  - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. 
} \newEntryVSpace \sectionsep
**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
- Your output should be raw LaTeX code and should not be in a code block.

**Task Details**:
1. **Section Header**:
   - Begin with a `\section{VOLUNTEER}` command if volunteer data is available. If no data is provided, the output should remain empty.

2. **Organization Name**:
   - Use `\subsection{}` for organization name less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\smallSubSection{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.

3. **Role and Timeline**:
   - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Organization | Year-Year`. Use `\subTitle{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.

4. **Responsibilities**:
   - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) and end with `\\` for line breaks, exepct the last one. 

5. **Adding Another Entry**:
    - If there are multiple volunteer entries, use `\newEntryVSpace` to separate each entry and maintain a consistent structure.
   
6. **Section Separator**:
   - Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections.

7. **Special Character Handling**:
   - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
     - `%` to `\%`
     - `$` to `\$`
     - `&` to `\&`
     - `#` to `\#`
     - `_` to `\_`

**Example Outputs**:
**Example 1**: First Decide if to use `\subsection{}` or `\smallSubSection{}` based on the length of the organization name for all entries. The command should be same for all entries.
\section{VOLUNTEER}
  \subsection{.dev Programming Club} or swap with \smallSubSection{.dev Programming Club} 
  \subTitle{Active Member | University of Manitoba Students Union (UMSU) | 2019-2023}
  \body{
    - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\
    - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. 
  }
  \newEntryVSpace
  \sectionsep

**Conditions**: - Only generate the `\section{VOLUNTEER}` if there is at least one volunteer entry. If no entries are provided, the output should be latex comments, starting with '%'.
  %\section{}
  %\sectionsep.
- Your output should be raw LaTeX code and should not be in a code block.

2024-06-06 23:04:57: task=```
% VOLUNTEER Section %

% Check if there are volunteer entries
\IfEq{\fpeval{\listlen{Volunteer Work}}}{0}{\relax}{\section{VOLUNTEER}}

% Iterate through volunteer entries
\ForEach{\VolunteerEntry}{Volunteer Work} {
  % Determine the appropriate organizational name command based on length
  \IfEq{\fpeval{\strLen{Organization Name}}}{20}{\subsection{\Organization Name}}{\smallSubSection{\Organization Name}}

  % Output organizational name and role/timeline
  \subTitle{\Role | \Timeline}

  % Add responsibilities
  \body{
    \ForEach{\Responsibility}{\Responsibilities} {
      - \Responsibility \\
    }
  }

  % Separate multiple entries
  \newEntryVSpace
}

% Section separator
\sectionsep
```2024-06-06 23:04:57: status=completed

2024-06-06 23:08:23: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
In your output, follow these guidelines:
- The first line should contain the section name "VOLUNTEER". Use the command `\section{VOLUNTEER}`. - Each volunteer entry should be structured as follows:
  - Use `\subsection{}` for organization names less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\smallSubSection{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.
  - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Timeline`. Use `\subTitle{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.
  - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) and end with `\\` for line breaks.
  - Use `\newEntryVSpace` to separate each volunteer entry and maintain a consistent structure.
- Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections. - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
  - `%` to `\%`
  - `$` to `\$`
  - `&` to `\&`
  - `#` to `\#`
  - `_` to `\_`

Example: First Decide if to use `\subsection{}` or `\smallSubSection{}` based on the length of the organization name for all entries. The command should be same for all entries.
\section{VOLUNTEER}
  \subsection{.dev Programming Club} or swap with \smallSubSection{.dev Programming Club}

  \body{
    - Engaged with the latest software development technologies and tools. \\ 
    - Collaborated on team projects focused on Python and Cloud Technologies. 
  }

  % \sectionsep.
- Your output should be raw LaTeX code and should not be in a code block.

2024-06-07 09:46:45: task=Convert the volunteer work information of the applicant from the provided data into the LaTeX format, focusing on organization, clarity, and adherence to LaTeX syntax conventions.
In your output, follow these guidelines:
- The first line should contain the section name "VOLUNTEER". Use the command `\section{VOLUNTEER}`. - Each volunteer entry should be structured as follows:
  - Use `\subsection{}` for organization names less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\smallSubSection{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.
  - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Timeline`. Use `\subTitle{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.
  - List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) and end with `\\` for line breaks.
  - Use `\newEntryVSpace` to separate each volunteer entry and maintain a consistent structure.
- Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections. - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
  - `%` to `\%`
  - `$` to `\$`
  - `&` to `\&`
  - `#` to `\#`
  - `_` to `\_`

Example: First Decide if to use `\subsection{}` or `\smallSubSection{}` based on the length of the organization name for all entries. The command should be same for all entries.

2024-06-07 09:50:01: task=Extract the education information of the applicant from the provided data. Then convert the extracted data into the LaTeX format. If you don't find any information at all, the output should be completely empty.
In the output, - The first line contains the section name "Education". Use the command \section{Education}. - The next lines contain the education information with the following format:
  - The first line contains the institution name. Use the command \customTitle{Institution Name}.
  - The next line contains the degree and major. Use the command \semiTitle{Degree and Major}.
  - The next line contains the graduation status and date. Use the command \subTitle{Graduation Status, Graduation Date}.
  - The next line contains the command \newEntryVSpace to separate the educations. Only use this command if there are multiple educations. Otherwise, do not use this command.
  - Do not choose more than two educations. Choose the most recent ones.

Example: \section{Education}
  \customTitle{University of Manitoba}
  \semiTitle{BSc Major in Computer Science}
  \subTitle{Graduated, October 2023}

  \newEntryVSpace % use it if there are multiple educations to separate them.

In your output, follow these guidelines:
- The first line should contain the section name "VOLUNTEER". Use the command `\section{VOLUNTEER}`. - Each volunteer entry should be structured as follows:
  - Use `\subsection{}` for organization names less than 20 characters. If any organization name exceeds 20 characters, use `\smallSubSection{}` to maintain visual consistency for all Organization names entries.
  - Present the role and the timeline of the volunteer activity in the format: `Role | Timeline`. Use `\subTitle{}` for this line to maintain visual hierarchy and readability.
  - Next inside \body{} List each responsibility starting with a dash (`-`) and end with '\\' then a `\vspace{5pt}` for line breaks.
  - Use `\newEntryVSpace` to separate each volunteer entry and maintain a consistent structure.
- Conclude the volunteer section with `\sectionsep` to maintain consistent spacing between sections. - Convert special LaTeX characters to their escaped versions to prevent errors in LaTeX processing:
  - `%` to `\%`
  - `$` to `\$`
  - `&` to `\&`
  - `#` to `\#`
  - `_` to `\_`

Example: First Decide if to use `\subsection{}` or `\smallSubSection{}` based on the length of the organization name for all entries. The command should be same for all entries.

2024-06-07 09:57:05: task=```latex
% Check if there are any volunteer entries
\ifthenelse{\isempty{\VolunteerWork}}{
  % No volunteer entries, so output latex comments
  % \section{VOLUNTEER}
  % \sectionsep
}{
  % There are volunteer entries, so generate the section
  \section{VOLUNTEER}
  % Loop through each volunteer entry
  \foreach \VolunteerEntry in \VolunteerWork {
    % Replace special LaTeX characters with escaped versions
    \renewcommand*{\OrganizationName}{\expandafter\escapestring\expandafter{\VolunteerEntry["Organization Name"]}}
    \renewcommand*{\Role}{\expandafter\escapestring\expandafter{\VolunteerEntry["Role"]}}
    \renewcommand*{\Timeline}{\expandafter\escapestring\expandafter{\VolunteerEntry["Timeline"]}}
    \renewcommand*{\Responsibilities}{\expandafter\escapestring\expandafter{\VolunteerEntry["Responsibilities"]}}

    % Use \subsection{} or \smallSubSection{} based on the length of the organization name
    \ifthenelse{\length{\OrganizationName} > 20}{
      \smallSubSection{\OrganizationName}
    }{
      \subsection{\OrganizationName}
    }

    % Output the role and timeline
    \subTitle{\Role | \Timeline}

    % Output the responsibilities
    \body{
      -\Responsibilities\\ \vspace{5pt}
    }

    % Add a vertical space to separate each entry
    \newEntryVSpace
  }

  % Add a vertical space to separate the volunteer section from the next section
  \sectionsep
}
